Manx: Parick Noo bannee yn Ellan ain: dy bannee eh shin as yn baatey goll magh dy mie, cheet stiagh ny share, lesh bio as marroo ’sy vaatey.
English: St. Patrick who blessed our Island; may he bless us and the boat going out well, coming in better, with living and dead in the boat.

Manx: Dy bannee yn Noo Pharick shin as nyn maatey, goll magh dy mie as çheet stiagh ny share, ooilley bio as ny merriu marin.
English: May St. Patrick bless us and our boat, going out well and coming in better, all alive and the dead with us. [Prayers formerly said by fishermen when putting out to sea.]

Manx: Tra çhionniey ta’n streng s’lickley da brishey.
English: When the string is tightest it is nearest to breaking. [A fisherman's saying which means luck will turn when things are worst.]

Manx: Fuinney thanney er y veggan meinney.
English: Baking thin with little meal (i.e., making great show of nothing).

Manx: Raad ta moyrnagh ta boghtynid.
English: Where there is pride there is poverty.

Manx: Raad ta boghtynid çheet te jannoo edd.
English: Where poverty comes it makes a nest.

Manx: S’booiagh yn voght er yn veggan.
English: The poor are content with a little.

Manx: Daa red dwoaiagh — boght moyrnagh as dooinney-seyr breagagh.
English: Two hateful things — a poor person proud and a gentleman telling lies.

Manx: Tra cha vel yn argid çheet stiagh, ta’n graih goll magh er yn uinnag.
English: When money does not come in, love goes out at the window. (English equivalent—When poverty comes in at the door love flies out at the window.)

Manx: Ta ny smoo poosey na vod freayll cowree feayr ayns y cupboard.

Manx: Cha daink rieau feayraght dys haink yn arragh.
English: Cold never comes until spring, and never comes hardship until buying (i.e., until ’tis time to pay).

Manx: As daink rieau creoighyn dys haink yn chionnagh.
Cha der oo enn er ommidan mannngh jean oo clashtyn eh loayrt.
English: You will not know a fool unless you hear him speak.
Another version is—

English: You will not know a fool unless you hear him speak.

Manx: Cur bleb er çhaghteraght as nee uss fakm cre’n sorch çhaghter nee eh jannoo.
English: Send a fool on a message and you will see what kind of a messenger he will make.

Manx: Ta poddash heh mie da moddee aegey.
English: Hot porridge is good for young dogs (i.e., “Experience teaches fools”).

Manx: Nee rouyr eeym toghtey moddey.
English: Too much butter will choke a dog.

Manx: Our craue da moddey greimmey.
English: Give a bone to a snappy dog.
Another version is—

Manx: Ceau craue ayns beeal drogh voddey, son cha jean moddee mie cur eh eie ort.
English: Throw a bone into a bad dog's mouth for a good dog won't meddle with thee.

Manx: Ta feill yn kiark ghoo cha mie as feill y kiark bane.
English: The flesh of the black hen is as good as the flesh of the white hen.

Manx: Baase mraane as bishagey kirree.
English: Death of women and increase of sheep.

Manx: Gow magh dy lhoam, trooid thie dy mullagh, lesh yn eayn bwoirrin as yn coamrey sonney.
English: Go out bare, come home rough, with the she lamb and the plentiful fleece. [Charm formerly said after sheepshearing.]

Manx: Eiyrt yn bock ta goll.
English: Drive the horse that goes.

Manx: Eshyn ta çeet toshiaght dys mwyllin yiow eh chied blieh.
English: He who first comes to the mill gets his grist first ground;
i.e., “First come first served.” This was formerly the case both at mill and smithy; every one had his turn.x
The following proverb shows that Manx milllers were not more honest than their brethren in England : —
It was the custom for the miller to grind the farmer’s corn, and to pay himself by taking foilliu.
foilliu] “Mulcture, toll given at a mill for grinding.” (Cregeen).

Manx: Goaill foilliu daa keayrt.
English: Taking mulcture twice. [An epithet applied to a dishonest person.]

Manx: Te kiark boght nagh vod screebey son ny eean.
English: “Tis a poor hen which cannot scratch for one chicken.

Manx: Sharie ny lomarcan na drogh cumraagyn.
English: Better alone than in bad company.

Manx: S’mi yn red ta couyral.
English: Good is the thing which mends.

Manx: Lhig mee-hene goll toshiaght.
English: Let myself go first. [The saying is applied to an egotistical person.]

Manx: Cha lhiass dhyt goll dys yn jouyl son cairys choud as t’eh cur briwnys.
English: Thou need’st not go to the devil for justice so long as he gives judgment.
Another version is —

Manx: Cha lhiass dhyt goll dys leigh my ta’n jouyl soie son briwnys.
English: Thou neeed’s not go to law if the devil sits for judgment (i.e., ‘Do not expect justice from the devil”).

Manx: Ta eeayst Jesarn ’sy Vayrnt as eayst Jesarn ’syn ouyr.
English: A Saturday’s moon in March and a Saturday's moon in harvest is too much once in seven years.

Manx: Keayrt ayns shiaght bleeantyn rouyr.

English: It is said that Saiurday’s new moon only falls once in seven years in March and harvest, and it always brought storm and ruin. Hence it was considered unlucky — coming once in seven years too often.

English: Unless the sun shines on the Hill of the Desert on Old New Year Day, there will not be a good herring year.

Manx: Hie yn chriy mygeayrt sheear un laa,
English: The gallows went around west on day,

The gallows was once swept off Hango Hill by the sea, and washed in on the Niarbyl shore, after which Southside men returned the taunt to their fellows in the West by saying that when the very gallows went round West to hang them it showed how bad they were.

Manx: Va eirey mooar ayns Rhaby mooar,
English: There was a great heir in Raby Mooar,

Manx: As eirey mooar ayns Ballelby.
English: And a great heir in Ballelby.

Manx: Ny sodjey sheear ny smessey sthill,
English: Further west worse still,

Manx: Pyht, pyht, pyht, er vooinjer Ghelby.
English: Pyht, pyht, pyht, on the people of Dalby.

When this was sung, the thumbs were snapped at “Pyht.” A Peel man would say it in the same circumstances as an Irishman would invite one “to stand on his coat.” It was a challenge to a fight, and the finger-snapping expressed derision. It was sung to a dance tune.
FRAGMENTARY LOVE SONGS.

Manx: “Graih my chree, vel graih ayd orrym?”
English: Love of my heart, hast thou love for me?”

Manx: “Ta, red beg cha nel mee follym.”
English: “A little I have to give to thee.”

Manx: Voish yn red beg haink graih mooar
English: From that little soon came more.

Manx: As lurg shen haink graih dy-liooar.
English: Then came love in fullest store.

Manx: O! she yn traa va my ghraih’s beaghey ayns y Lagg,
English: Oh! It is the time my love was living in the Lagg,#

Manx: V’ish ceau ny goonyn sheidey as ny bussalyn plaid;
English: She was wearing gowns of silk and hand-kerchiefs of plaid:

Manx: Son v’ish ben aeg cha aalin — cha naik shiu rieau ny s’booie,
English: For she was a maiden young one fairer ne’er you saw.

Manx: V’ish ’skyn dy-chooilley lady ayns ny skeeraghyn twoaie.
English: Fairer far than any lady dwelling in the Nor’.

Manx: Co-chiaull.
English: Chorus.

Manx: O! she jeelt shiu dou my chabbyl dy voddym nish goll roym
English: ’Tis saddle you for me my horse that swiftly ride I may,

Manx: Dy akin graih veg veen my chree son t’ish feer foddey voym;
English: All for to see my heart’s dear love who’s very far away :

Manx: Hem’s harrish crink as couanyn as derrey er mee skee.
English: O’er hill and dale I'll go, though worn and weary I may be.

Manx: Dy akin graih veg veen my chree son t’ish feer foddey j'ee.
English: To see my heart’s dear little love—far, far away is she.
